result.text:
The CCPâ€™s Power Plays in Tariff Talks Explained | Chairman John Moolenaar

@RepMoolenaar (R-Mich.) has been spearheading efforts in Congress to combat the threat posed by the Chinese regime to American interestsâ€”from economic warfare to espionage and infiltrationâ€”as chairman of the House Select Committee on the Chinese Communist Party (@ChinaSelect).

â€œWith rare earths, China is basically firing a loaded gun ... on our economy,â€ he says.

Heâ€™s pushing a bill that would phase in a 100 percent tariff on all strategic goods from China. The tariff would not just penalize China but also incentivize â€œother countries, as well as the United States, to invest in this almost as if it's a Defense Production Act activity.â€

Beyond rare earth minerals, what leverage does the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) have exactly in trade talks with the United States? What will the CCPâ€™s strategy be? How should President Donald Trump respond to the CCPâ€™s coercive tactics and its recent attempts to gain additional leverage?

And what can America do to extricate itself from its dependence on China for some of its most critical manufacturing technologies?

Moolenaar points out that the CCP is using its leverage not only over trade but also over Chinese nationals studying or working in America via its extensive United Front operations.

â€œUnder their recent national security laws, any Chinese national who doesn't carry out the will of the Chinese Communist Party, no matter where they are in the world, on U.S. soil or somewhere else in the world, [is] in violation of national security laws,â€ Moolenaar says.

On the other hand, is the position of the CCP really secure? And what about Chinese leader Xi Jinpingâ€™s position in particular? What signs of dissatisfaction and unrest are there among the Chinese population?

Views expressed in this video are opinions of the host and the guest, and do not necessarily reflect the views of The Epoch Times.

legacy.full_text:
First paper published by Meta Superintelligence Labs!

In this paper, they make RAG faster by swapping most retrieved tokens for precomputed & reusable chunk embeddings, called REFRAG

This method improves its speed by 30x and fitting 16x longer contexts without accuracy loss https://t.co/Tf7oWoqowp

Everything Elon Musk clarified today about the ð• algorithm powered by Grok:

â€¢ Xâ€™s recommendation system is evolving fast, all old heuristics will be deleted within 4â€“6 weeks.

â€¢ The new system will rely fully on AI powered by Grok.

â€¢ Grok will read every post and watch over 100M+ videos per day to learn what users find interesting.

â€¢ Its goal is to match each user with content theyâ€™re most likely to enjoy or engage with.

â€¢ This will help fix the small or new account problem, where good posts often go unseen.

â€¢ Youâ€™ll soon be able to ask Grok directly to adjust your feed, either temporarily or permanently.

â€¢ Elon clarified that the algorithm does not randomly boost or hide posts.

â€¢ It simply assesses which posts are likely to interest users, similar to how a human judges content.

â€¢ Posts with bare links or little context will have weaker distribution and the posts with strong, interesting descriptions or images will get better visibility.

â€¢ The systemâ€™s only goal is to show users the most relevant and engaging content.

HeyGen just hit $100M ARR this month, 29 months after we first reached $1M in April 2023.

None of this happens without our incredible team, customers, partners, and community. Thank you ðŸ’œ

When we shared our first $1M milestone, it was to give back to the build-in-public community. The AI landscape has changed completely since then, but one thing hasnâ€™t: how we build.

Internally, weâ€™ve called it our â€œbible,â€ the system thatâ€™s guided us from $1M to $100M. Itâ€™s built from countless team discussions, experiments, and lessons learned along the way. After much reflection, I wanted to document whatâ€™s worked for us â€” for our team and for everyone building in AI.

Weâ€™re sharing it not because itâ€™s perfect, but because itâ€™s working. Itâ€™s how we deliver customer value, learn faster than the world changes, and keep riding the wave.

This is The HeyGen Way.

result.text:
The ð• recommendation system is evolving very rapidly. We are aiming for deletion of all heuristics within 4 to 6 weeks.

Grok will literally read every post and watch every video (100M+ per day) to match users with content theyâ€™re most likely to find interesting. 

This should address the new user or small account problem, where you post something great, but nobody sees it. 

We will also be adding the ability for you to adjust your feed temporarily or permanently just by asking Grok.

How the ð• algorithm really works?

The algorithm doesnâ€™t boost or hide posts randomly, it just tries to figure out if your post will be interesting to people.

That means:

If you post a plain link with no words, the algorithm doesnâ€™t have much to judge, so it wonâ€™t show it to many people.

But if you add a good caption, image, or more context, it spreads more.

Basically, the algorithm needs enough info to understand why your post matters, just like a human would.

The conversation shifts to NVIDIA's AI supercomputer developments where Huang recounts announcing the DGX-1 in 2016 which got little response except from Musk. The video ends with casual thanks and the location Stavis mentioned.

result.text:
ok so let me explain why subagents kill long context

Like you can spend $500m building 100 million context models, and they would be 1) slow, 2) expensive to use, 3) have huge context rot. O(n) is the lower bound. 

Cog's approach is something you learn in day 1 of @CS50 - divide and parallelize. Embeddings are too dumb, Agentic Search is too slow. So train limited-agency (max 4 turns), natively parallel tool calling (avg parallelism of 7-8, custom toolset) fast (2800tok/s) subagents to give the performance of Agentic Search under an acceptable "Flow Window" that feels immaterially slower than Embeddings.

The benefit of this is threefold:
- 8 ^ 4 toolcalls cover a very large code search space. can compound subagent calls if more needed.
- predictable cost & end to end latency
- subagent outputs "clean" contexts, free of context failure modes like context poisoning and context rot (h/t @dbreunig )

we originally called this Rapid Agentic Search, to contrast with RAG. but Fast Context rolls of the tongue better.

there's 2 other perspectives that are worthwhile, i'll go into below, but just go try it out. here it is on @karpathy's fastchat

result.post_image_description: The image contains screenshots of text instructions related to the use of a tool called 'Claude Code' for managing tasks. The first screenshot explains various tools available in Claude Code, such as Launch, Read, Edit, Write, and others, detailing their functions and usage scenarios. The second screenshot describes the 'TodoRead' tool, which is used to ensure the user is aware of the current to-do list status. The third screenshot discusses the 'Task' tool within Claude Code, which essentially clones itself to handle subtasks, allowing for parallel processing and focused context management. This method is likened to recursion, where Claude Code can spawn sub-agents to handle specific parts of a larger task, like debugging code and writing tests, by breaking down the process into manageable steps and updating the to-do list accordingly.
result.post_video_description: The video showcases a demonstration of the AI tool 'Claude Code' and its functionality in managing multitasking through the use of sub-agents. The post explains how Claude Code can create sub-tasks using the 'Task' tool, which essentially clones itself to handle specific parts of a larger task, such as debugging code and writing tests. The video frames display a computer screen with code editors open, showing the process of task delegation and context management within Claude Code. This method allows for parallel task execution and focused context for sub-tasks, enhancing efficiency. The visual elements include code snippets and task lists, illustrating the practical application of the described process.

result.text:
Falcon launch #130 for 2025. The rolling 365 launch total is 166 launches! 

Notable records from this morning:
* Fastest launch to launch from the same American Launch Pad at 55 Hrs, 29 minutes and 9 seconds 
* Fastest TE roll in to hangar for booster integration to launch at 12 Hrs, 5 minutes, 20 seconds 

Iâ€™m confident the @SpaceX Falcon team will pull off a sub 48 hour launch to launch turn from Pad 40 this year. We still have some work to do best the world record the Soviets in 1962 with Vostok 3 and Vostok 4 from the same pad in 24 hours (two different ground launch systems so not totally apples to apples, but nonetheless the record!) 

Of course, we will all look back and laugh at these records once Starship is ripping multiple launches a day from the same pad ðŸš€ðŸš€ðŸš€
